prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 3C 210 - CO(6-5)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We want to observe to CO 6-5 line (rest freq. 691 GHz) to trace the warm gas distribution in this merger system. One baseband will be centered on the (redshifted) line in TDM correlator mode, which gives sufficient velocity resolution for our purposes (the line width is ~ 400-500 km/s). The other three basebands are placed evenly through the band, avoiding absorption lines, and are also set to TDM correlator mode to observe the continuum emission from cold dust around 430 microns rest frequency.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Typical line widths for this line in similar merging systems are typically around 400 km/s but can range from 100 to 1000 km/s in the most extreme cases (~4 to 30 elements per line width). However, the line strengths are not expected to be high enough to justify any resolution higher than available in the TDM mode, which is sufficient to resolve the line with good S/N.

The requested scale matches our existing infrared imaging (HST pixel size of 0.13") and is a good baseline for comparison between host galaxy structures and the gas/dust emission traced by ALMA. Typical galaxy separations are on the order of a few arcseconds at most, and even the largest galaxies have an extent less than 3". Thus 5" is our largest angular scale required.

There are multiple sources in the field of view; the brightest is the synchrotron jet at the center of the main galaxy, which has a peak flux density at 100 GHz of 100 mJy. In the ALMA bands the bright 'core' will likely be lower than this but we take this as our upper limit as the jet can be variable. The main science targets are the extended gas, traced by CO (7-6) line, and the extended continuum cold dust emission. Scaling from observations of the same line in similar nearby AGN, we expect a peak line flux of about 20 mJy, so the observations give a reasonable S/N of 50 given the uncertainties. This is a somewhat conservative estimate from a single galaxy with a total gas mass of 10^9 Msol, and could easily be larger for the large merging systems we target. For the continuum in band 7 (observed by the remaining 3 passbands), we expect to see cold dust emission (temperature ~ 20K) with a S/N of ~ 40.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 3C 210 - CO(3-2)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We want to observe to CO 3-2 line (rest freq. 345 GHz) to trace the cold gas distribution in this merger system. One baseband will be centered on the (redshifted) line in TDM correlator mode, which gives sufficient velocity resolution for our purposes (the line width is ~ 400-500 km/s). The other three basebands are placed evenly through the band, avoiding absorption lines, and area also set to TDM correlator mode to observe the continuum emission.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Typical line widths for this line in similar merging systems are typically around 400-500 km/s but can range from 100 to 1000 km/s in the most extreme cases (~2 to 16 elements per line width). However, the line strengths are not expected to be high enough to justify any resolution higher than available in the TDM mode, which is sufficient to resolve the line with good S/N in practically all cases.

The requested scale is close (0.25") to our existing infrared imaging (HST pixel sizes 0.13") and is a good baseline for comparison between host galaxy structures and the gas/dust emission traced by ALMA. Typical galaxy separations are on the order of a few arcseconds at most, and even the largest galaxies have an extent less than 3". Thus 5" is our largest angular scale required.

There are multiple sources in the field of view; the brightest is the relativistic jet at the center of the main galaxy, which has a peak luminosity at 100 GHz of 100 mJy. In the ALMA bands the bright 'core' will likely be lower than this but we take this as our upper limit as the jet can be variable. The main science targets are the extended gas, traced by CO (3-2) line, and the extended continuum dust emission. Scaling from observations of the same line in nearby AGN, we expect a peak line flux of about 10 mJy, so the observations give a reasonable S/N of 35. This is a somewhat conservative estimate from a single galaxy with a total gas mass of 10^9 Msol, and could easily be larger for the large merging systems we target. For the continuum in band 4 (observed by the remaining 3 passbands), we expect to see mainly synchrotron emission from the radio jet, and possibly dust emission with S/N~6 (dust emission in band 4 will be about 10x fainter than in band 7).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We want to observe to CO 6-5 line (rest freq. 691 GHz) to trace the warm gas distribution in this merger system. Typical galaxy separations are on the order of a few arcseconds at most, and even the largest galaxies have an extent less than 3". Thus 5" is our largest angular scale required.

The main science targets are the extended gas, traced by CO (7-6) line, and the extended continuum cold dust emission. Scaling from observations of the same line in similar nearby AGN, we expect a peak line flux of about 20 mJy, so the observations give a reasonable S/N of 50. This is a somewhat conservative estimate from a single galaxy with a total gas mass of 10^9 Msol, and could easily be larger for the large merging systems we target. For the continuum in band 7 (observed by the remaining 3 passbands), we expect to see cold dust emission (temperature ~ 20K) with a S/N of ~ 70.

However, the line strengths are not expected to be high enough to justify any resolution higher than available in the TDM mode, which is sufficient to resolve the line with good S/N in practically all cases.

The requested scale is close (0.25") to our existing infrared imaging (HST pixel sizes 0.13") and is a good baseline for comparison between host galaxy structures and the gas/dust emission traced by ALMA. Typical galaxy separations are on the order of a few arcseconds at most, and even the largest galaxies have an extent less than 3". Thus 5" is our largest angular scale required.

The main science targets are the extended gas, traced by CO (3-2) line, and the extended continuum dust emission. Scaling from observations of the same line in nearby AGN, we expect a peak line flux of about 20 mJy, so the observations give a reasonable S/N of 32. This is a somewhat conservative estimate from a single galaxy with a total gas mass of 10^9 Msol, and could easily be larger for the large merging systems we target. For the continuum in band 4 (observed by the remaining 3 passbands), we expect to see mainly synchrotron emission from the radio jet, and possibly dust emission with S/N~6 (dust emission in band 4 will be about 10x fainter than in band 7).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: It is still not known what triggers the large-scale relativistic jets found in about 10% of AGN. Our group has recently found that radio-loud (jetted) AGN at redshifts of z=1-3 are always found in merging systems, compared with a typical fraction of ~40% of radio-quiet (non-jetted) AGN, in agreement with results at lower redshifts. This result holds for the most powerful down to the lowest-luminosity AGN observed, suggesting that some properties of mergers are responsible for switching on the jet, and must differ from the properties of mergers hosting quiescent galaxies and radio-quiet AGN. In order to better understand what properties of the merger play the key role in producing jets, we propose moderately high-resolution imaging of the CO molecular gas (both cold and warm phase) for a matched sample of merging systems, including 5 high-power jetted AGN, 4 very low-power jetted AGN, and 5 non-jetted AGN at z=1-2, for which we have HST imaging in near-IR and optical. The proposed observations will allow us to examine in detail the distribution of the cold and warm gas, dust, and star formation, and to make progress in understanding how the merger properties trigger jet formation.
